title-group.article-title: Hybrid under-actuated control for autonomous dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle including motor dynamics and in the presence of huge uncertainty

article-meta.aff: Department of Electrical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan, Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Hsiu-Ming Wu, Opto-Mechatronics Technology Center, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, 43, Section 4, Keelung Road, Taipei, 106 Taiwan, Republic of China Email: D9307205@mail.ntust.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Hybrid under-actuated control for the autonomous dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle including frictional torque and motor dynamics is developed, which includes two control inputs: steering and pendulum voltages, and three system outputs: steering, lean and pendulum angles. Due to the under-actuated feature, two novel reference signals using three system outputs are designed so that the number of control inputs and sliding surfaces is the same. According to the input-output data of each subsystem, two scaling factors for each subsystem are first employed to normalize the sliding surface and its derivative. Based on the concept of if-then rule, an appropriate rule table for the ith subsystem is obtained. The output scaling factor based on Lyapunov stability is also determined. It is called fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control (FDSMUC). Because the uncertainties of a running electrical bicycle system, caused by different ground conditions, gusts of wind, and interactions among subsystems, are often huge, an extra compensation of learning uncertainty is plunged into FDSMUC to enhance the system performance. We call it fuzzy decentralized sliding mode adaptive under-actuated control (FDSMAUC). To avoid the unnecessary transience caused by uncertainties and preserve the dynamic balance, the combination of FDSMUC and FDSMAUC with a transition (i.e., Hybrid FDSMUC) is suggested. The stability of the closed-loop system using the proposed control is verified by Lyapunov stability theorem. Finally, the compared simulations validate the efficiency among the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Under-actuated control has already been discussed in some papers. An under-actuated control was applied to the well-known swing up and balancing control problem of the inverted pendulum (Fierro et al., 1996). Begovich et al. (2002) presented a Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy scheme for the real-time trajectory tracking of an under-actuated robot: the Pendubot. Tarn et al. (2005) summarized recent theoretical output regulation for nonlinear systems with an experimental study of under-actuated mechanical system: the Pendubot. In summary, the unstable feature of an under-actuated control system makes the corresponding control problem more difficult. Another paper proposed by Grasser et al. (2002) introduced a novel control method for two-wheeled vehicles that was operated by shifting the driver’s weight. Then, there were two papers respectively from Tanaka and Murakami (2004) and Niki and Murakami (2005), which realized stable bicycle running through controlling the steering angle of a bicycle’s handle. Recently, the stability of the bicycle at low speed was studied by Iuchi et al. (2005). Astrom et al. (2005) discussed the dynamics and control of bicycles via a linearized approach as well. These control methodologies only forced the operating point into the vicinity of the desired posture or drive the operating point to the target near the desired attitude. Based on the above-mentioned studies, a running electrical bicycle possesses complicated nonlinear dynamics as well as under-actuated characteristic.

In the past, a nonlinear control scheme for an under-actuated acrobot has been constructed by Berkemeier and Fearing (1999). In fact, for the trajectory of 1 Hz, no tracking error was committed by their controller, as opposed to the tracking error of 13∘ by the pseudolinearizing controller. Recently, a paper developed by Yamaguchi et al. (2007) using acceleration based backstepping control confirmed that a nonlinear control for an electrical bicycle is better than that of conventional control. Summing up the conclusion reached by previous works, the control of a bicycle’s center of gravity (CG) and steering handle angle are the two most important factors in realizing a stable running motion. Inthese situations, it is difficult for an electrical bicycleto obtain autonomous dynamic balance when it is encountered with huge uncertainties, e.g., varying ground conditions and external disturbances in the air. It is also known that the experimental study of the dynamic balance of a bicycle is not an easy task. In order to consider a bicycle system model completely, the inclusion of frictional torque and motor dynamics by Chen et al. (1988) is necessary. However, it forms a high dimensional model such that the controller design is more complex. Under these circumstances, the proposed Hybrid fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control (Hybrid FDSMUC) for a running electrical bicycle including frictional torque and motor dynamics and in the presence of huge uncertainty is applied to deal with exactly what linear control schemes cannot reach. These huge uncertainties are often caused by varying ground conditions (e.g., wet, muddy, concrete grounds) and unexpected gusts of wind.

In general, a fuzzy control algorithm (Sadati and Talasaz, 2006; Ho and Niu, 2007; Li et al., 2009; Chen, 2010) consists of a set of heuristic decision rules and is regarded as a non-mathematical control algorithm, which has been proved to be very attractive whenever the controlled systems cannot be well defined or modeled. However, it needs a trial-and-error method to obtain an acceptable tracking performance. In thispaper, the combination of sliding-mode control, decentralized control, and fuzzy control, which is so-called fuzzy decentralized sliding-mode control (FDSMC), provides a robust controller for the nonlinear systems (Banavar and Dominic, 1999; Li and Yam, 2001; Khaled and Chalhoub, 2010). Moreover, this paper introduces an FDSMC scheme with the number of outputs larger than that of the control inputs (Hwang et al., 2009). This specific type of FDSMC is the so-called fuzzy decentralized sliding mode (adaptive) under-actuated control (FDSMUC or FDSMAUC or Hybrid FDSMUC). The use of FDSMUC or FDSMAUC or Hybrid FDSMUC is dependent on the quantity of the uncertainty including all kind of initial errors, different ground conditions, and gust of wind. The following two paragraphs will discuss how to design the proposed three-steps Hybrid FDSMUC.

Owing to the under-actuated feature of a running electrical bicycle system, two novel reference signals are first designed so that the uncontrolled mode (i.e., the angle, velocity and acceleration of lean) is simultaneously included into these two control modes (i.e., the angle, velocity and acceleration of handle and pendulum). The difference with the paper (Hwang et al., 2009) is in the extra consideration accelerations of lean, pendulum and steering due to the extra inclusion of motor dynamics. In this situation, the uncontrolled mode is indirectly manipulated by these two controllable modes. Two sliding surfaces are obtained from the linear combination of these two reference inputs. Then, the theorems about bounded-input-bounded-output (BIBO) and asymptotical tracking for the sliding surface are discussed. Based on the practical ranges of the sliding surface and its derivative, two normalizing scaling factors are selected. The fuzzy rule table of the ith subsystem using sliding surface and its derivative (i.e., the set of if-then rules) is achieved. The quantity ofthis fuzzy table is assigned as the value between −1 and 1. In addition, the crisp control input is determined from this table multiplying the output scaling factor, which is chosen according to the Lyapunov stability theorem. Generally speaking, as a larger output scaling factor is assigned, a smaller tracking error and a faster response will be obtained; however, the risk of transient response or oscillatory response occurs. The dynamic balance of a running bicycle is destroyed, let alone apossible instability or the excitation of unmodeled dynamics.

Under these conditions, the FDSMAUC is suggested to enhance the system performance. The difference between FDSMAUC and FDSMUC is that an extra compensation based on the learning uncertainty is plunged into FDSMUC. The purpose of this extra compensation is to reduce the uncertainties caused by different ground conditions (e.g., different tire pressure, wet ground, concrete ground), pulse disturbance due to wind effects, and interactions among subsystems. The learning law contains e-modification rate and projection to ensure the no-drift and boundedness of learning weight (Hwang, 2004). Furthermore, the proposed control only learns the uncertain function to promote better performance. That is different from most previous papers (e.g., Li et al., 2009; Yildirim et al., 2009): those learn the whole nonlinear functions. In this situation, the learning error becomes large; then it degrades the robust stability and robust performance (Chairez et al., 2009). To avoid the unnecessary transient response that destroys the dynamic balance, Hybrid FDSMUC (i.e., the combination of FDSMUC and FDSMAUC with a transition) is designed. The stabilities of the closed-loop system using FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC are verified by Lyapunov stability theory. The compared simulations considering time-varying uncertainty, in the presence of the pulse disturbance to represent a gust of wind for the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC are given. The main contribution of this paper includes the following two factors: (i) In order to complete the modeling of an electrical bicycle, the frictional torque and motor dynamics for both steering handle and pendulum are considered. The proposed Hybrid FDSMUC for this high dimensional model is constructed. (ii) An effective learning law is designed for the huge uncertainty, e.g., caused by different ground conditions, a gust of wind, and interactions among subsystems. Then the Hybrid FDSMUC is employed to deal with the unnecessary transience caused by FDSMAUC, which generally occurs for an on-line adaptive control scheme. Under this circumstance, the unbalance caused by uncertainties and control signal is prevented.

sec.title: 2.1. Modeling of a running electrical bicycle system
sec.p:
In the beginning, the control mechanism of an electrical bicycle in motion is depicted in Figure A.1 of Appendix A in which it can be composed of a front wheel part and a bicycle body with the pendulum part. The dynamic equation of the front wheel part can be derived from Newton-Euler equations and applied toques contain control torque of steering handle, gravity effect, precession effect, trail effect and internal coulomb friction force that are described as equation (A.1). In addition, the dynamic equations (A.2) and (A.3) can be obtained for a bicycle body with forward speed as well as a pendulum for balancing. The entire bicycle body can be regarded as a double pendulum with an actuator inthe middle of the two pendulums, whose dynamic model can be expressed as the acrobot dynamic model (Berkemeier and Fearing, 1999). Except for the nominal equations (A.1), (A.2) and (A.3), some unmodeled dynamics are supposed to exist (i.e., c(x,t) in (2)). Additionally, considering system more practically and completely, the frictional torques of steering handle and pendulum (i.e., (A.4) and (A.5)) and the dynamics of armature-controlled dc motors (i.e., (A.6) and (A.7)) are also included. Then the original 6th order system (e.g., Hwang et al., 2009) becomes an 8th order system. The corresponding variables are explained as follows: θ(t),φ1(t) and φ2(t) denote the steering, lean, and pendulum angles, respectively; i1(t) and i2(t) are the armature current of DC motors; τhan(t) and τpen(t) respectively represent the steering handle and pendulum torques; Ff1(x4) and Ff2(x6) are respectively the steering handle and pendulum frictional torques; u1(t)and u2(t) respectively represent the control inputs of the steering and pendulum voltages; the other system parameters are expressed and defined in the Table 1. sec.title: 2.2. Problem formulation
sec.p: Because the motion of an electrical bicycle system is often in different operating conditions (e.g., concrete ground, muddy ground, wet ground, different tire pressures, and in the face of a gust of wind), the dynamics of an electrical bicycle system is nonlinear, time variant and unstable. In this paper, it is assumed that the controlled system, i.e., a(x),B, and c(x,t), is unknown. However, the upper bounds of these functions are known.

The three steps for the proposed controller design are described as follows: Firstly, the FDSMUC, i.e., u(t)=uFDSMUC(t), which is based on the upper bounds of a(x), B, and c(x,t), is designed such that the outputs x1(t)=θ(t),x2(t)=φ1(t) and x3(t)=φ2(t) exponentially converge into a bounded set of zero, and that the dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle system is assured (Hwang et al., 2009). Since the running electrical bicycle system is in the presence of huge uncertainty, the FDSMUC is possibly not enough to deal with this situation. Secondly, the FDSMAUC, i.e., u(t)=uFDSMAUC(t), which is based on the low bounds of b1a(x)=b4'(x)η1b1>b1al>0, b2a(x)=b6'(x)η2b2>b2al>0 for all x(t), and the learning laws for the uncertainties is designed with an extra compensation of uncertainty. Under the subjection of huge uncertainty, the outputs x1(t)=θ(t),x2(t)=φ1(t) and x3(t)=φ2(t) exponentially converge into a bounded set of zero, and the dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle system in the presence of huge uncertainty is guaranteed. To prevent the unnecessary transience and preserve the dynamic balance, the combination of FDSMUC and FDSMAUC with a transition (i.e., Hybrid FDSMUC, u(t)=uHYB(t)) is finally designed such that the outputs x1(t)=θ(t),x2(t)=φ1(t) and x3(t)=φ2(t) exponentially and smoothly converge into a bounded set of zero, and that the autonomous dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle system in the presence of huge uncertainty is obtained (see Figure 1).

sec.title: 3. Sliding surface for under-actuated control system
sec.p: Since the proposed architecture is an under-actuated control system, the following two sliding surfaces need to be defined so that sliding mode under-actuated control can be designed step by step. (3)s1(t)=d1a(r··1(t)-x·4(t))+d1v(r·1(t)-x4(t))+d1p(r1(t)-x1(t)) (4)s2(t)=d2a(r··3(t)-x·6(t))+d2v(r·3(t)-x6(t))+d2p(r3(t)-x3(t)) where d1a,d1v,d1p,d2a,d2v,d2p>0 are assigned to obtain two stable sliding surfaces s1(t) and s2(t). Meanwhile, the reference inputs r1(t) and r3(t) are also assigned as (5) and (6) so that the uncontrolled mode x2(t) and x5(t) can be simultaneously included into the two control modes (i.e., x1(t),x3(t) or x4(t),x6(t)) to reach control indirectly via these controllable modes: (5)r1(t)=k1v(r·2(t)-x5(t))+k1p(r2(t)-x2(t)) (6)r3(t)=k2v(r·2(t)-x5(t))+k2p(r2(t)-x2(t)) where k1v,k1p,k2v,k2p>0 are set to obtain two stable reference inputs r1(t) and r3(t). In this paper, r2(t)=r·2(t)=r··2(t)=0 is considered. For simplicity, the tracking error is defined as follows: (7)ei(t)=ri(t)-xi(t),e·i(t)=ei+3(t),i=1,2,3

Before discussing the properties of FDSMUC (or FDSMAUC or Hybrid FDSMUC), the following twolemmas are given to depict the bounded-input-bounded-output and asymptotical tracking. Lemma 1
(Hwang, 1999) Consider the following dynamic equation: ¯·e(t)=Pe¯(t)+gs(t), where e¯(t)=[e(t)e·(t)]T, P=[01;-p2-p1]g=[01]T However, it is supposed that |s(t)|<λ and two positive constants p1 and p2 , then ||e¯(t0) || is bounded and there exist two positive constants k1 and k2 such that ||e¯(t) ||≤λk1/k2, as t→∞. Lemma 2
(Hwang, 1999) If the dynamics of the sliding surfaces (3) and (4) satisfy the inequality |s(t)|<α ||e¯(t) || for t≥t0 , where 0<α<k2/k1 , and its initial condition e¯(t0) is bounded, then |e(t)|,|e·(t)|→0 with a rate (k2-αk1) as t≥t0. Proof
See the reference (Hwang, 1997) for a similar result or Bellman-Gronwall inequality lemma (Desoer and Vidyasagar, 1975) and inequality obtains the result. Remark 1
Based on the Cayley-Hamilton Theorem, the matrix eP(t-t0) can be expressed as a 2×2 matrix.Then, k1 and k2 can be determined from ||exp[P(t-t0)] ||≤k1exp[-k2(t-t0)], ∀t≥t0≥0,and k2=-maxi=1,2ℜe{λi[P]}; hence, the value of α is found because 0<α<k2/k1. If the poles of the P matrix are all assigned at the more left region of the S plane, the value of α becomes smaller.

These two terms a·4'(x)anda·6'(x) can be respectively obtained from time derivative of (1d) and(1f). However, it is complicated to be represented. For simplicity, those are omitted.

sec.title: 4. The controller design
sec.p: The procedure of the proposed controller design is discussed in the following three subsections.

sec.title: 4.1. FDSMUC
sec.p: An important contribution of fuzzy systems theory is to provide a systematic procedure for transforming a set of linguistic rules into a nonlinear mapping. The fuzzy logic subsystem i for the FDSMUC performs a mapping from Xi∈ℜ2 to ℜ (e.g., allude to Figure 3 (Hwang et al., 2009)). There are l fuzzy control rules and the upper script k denotes the kth fuzzy rule: (12)IFs¯i(t)isF1ikand¯·si(t)isF2ik,THENu¯i(t)isGik where xi(t)=[s¯i(t)¯·si(t)]T∈Xi⊂ℜ2, with s¯i(t)=gsisi(t), ¯·si(t)=gs·is·i(t), and u¯i(t)∈Vi⊂ℜ are the input and output of the fuzzy logic subsystem i, respectively; Fjik(1≤i,j≤2,1≤k≤l) and Gik are labels ofsets in Xi and Vi, respectively. The scaling factors gsi and gs·i are chosen such that s¯i(t) and ¯·si(t)∈[-1,1]. The fuzzy inference engine performs a mapping fro m fuzzy sets in Xi⊂ℜ2 to fuzzy sets in Vi⊂ℜ , based upon the fuzzy IF-THEN rules in the fuzzy rule base and the compositional rule of inference. Let Axi be an arbitrary fuzzy set in Xi. The fuzzifier maps a crisp point xi(t) into a fuzzy set Axi in Xi. The center-average defuzzifier maps a fuzzy set in Vi to a crisp point inVi.

The output of the FDSMUC is then designed as follows: (13)ui(t)=ui,FDSMUC(t)=guiu¯i(t)=gui[si(t)+Δi(t)sgn(si)],i=1,2 where u¯i(t) is the fuzzy variable of ui(t), gui denotes theoutput scaling factor, and Δi(t)>0∀t denotes the switching gain, which is related to the Table 1. The output scaling factors are supposed to satisfy the following inequalities: (14)gu1≥g(g|h1(x,t)g|+λ1g)/g(d1ab1a(x)Δ1(t)g),gu2≥g(g|h2(x,t)g|+λ2g)/g(d2ab2a(x)Δ2(t)g), ∀t,x(t) where λ1,λ2>0, and (15)h1(x,t)=d1ag(r··1(t)-ρ1(x)g)+d1vg(r··1(t)-a'4(x)gg-b'4(x)η1x7(t)-c4(x,t)g)+d1pg(r·1(t)-x4(t)-c1(x,t)g) (16)h2(x,t)=d2a(r··3(t)-ρ2(x))+d2v(r··3(t)-a6'(x)-b6'(x)η2x8(t)-c6(x,t))+d2p(r·3(t)-x6(t)-c3(x,t))

Then the following theorems discuss the properties of the FDSMUC. Theorem 1
Consider the unknown running electrical bicycle system (2) with the known upper bound of (14). The reference inputs satisfy the conditions |r1(t)|,|r3(t)|<max(k1p,k2p)|e2(t)| and |r·1(t)|,|r·3(t)|<k0|e·2(t)|, where k0 is a bounded positive constant, as t≥t0. Applying (13) to system (2) gives the finite time to reach the sliding surfaces (3) and (4). Thenxi(t),uj(t), for i=1,2,…,8,j=1,2, are ultimately uniformly bounded (UUB), and |xi(t)|→0, i=1,2,…,6, as t→∞. Proof
See the reference (Hwang et al., 2009) for a similar result. Theorem 2
It is continuous for the Theorem 1 that the inequality (14) is assumed to be satisfied outside of the following convex set: D={s1(t),s2(t)||s1(t)|<p0,|s2(t)|<q0}. In addition, the reference inputs satisfy the conditions: |r1(t)|<p1,|r·1(t)|<p2,|r3(t)|<q1, and |r·3(t)|<q2 as t≥t0. Then xi(t) and uj(t) for i=1,2,…,. 8,j=1,2, are UUB, and |x1(t)|<p1+p0k1/k2,|x2(t)|<max(p1/k1p,q1/k2p), |x3(t)|<q1+q0k3/k4, |x4(t)|<p2+p0k1/k2,|x5(t)|<2max(p1/k1v,q1/k2v), and |x6(t)|<q2+q0k3/k4 ast→∞. Proof
The corresponding result can be obtained from Lemma 5 and Theorem 1. Remark 3
Based on the above analysis, the fuzzy variables s¯i(t)=gsisi(t) and ¯·si(t)=gs·is·i(t),i=1,2 are quantized into the 11 qualitative fuzzy variables (i.e., l=11) . It is not necessary that eleven fuzzy rule must be selected. A smaller fuzzy rule (e.g., l=7) can also obtain an acceptable performance. The look-up table directly relating the inputs s¯i(t) and ¯·si(t) with the output can refer to the Table II of the paper (Hwang et al., 2009).

sec.title: 4.2. FDSMAUC
sec.p:
If the system uncertainties (15) or (16), i.e., hi(x,t),i=1,2, are huge, they must be learned (e.g., h∧i(x,t)=W∧iT(t)Ψ(x)) to compensate their effect (Hwang, 2004). It is assumed that the unknown signals hi(x,t) can be smoothly truncated outside of x(t)∈D(x) (a compact subset in ℜn) and ∀t≥0. Based on the learning model, an FDSMAUC is then constructed to improve the system performance. First, the following extension of universal approximation theory is stated (Chairez et al., 2009; Hwang, 2009): Theorem 3
Suppose x(t)∈D(x) (a compact subset of ℜn) , h(x,t):D×ℜ+→ℜ is a continuous function. For an arbitrary constant ɛ>0, there exists an integerL (the number of hidden neurons) and real constantmatrix W¯∈ℜL×1 , where ||W¯ ||≤Wm, such that h(x,t)=W¯TΨ(x)+ɛh(x,t), where Ψ(x) denotes a known basis function, |ɛh(x,t)|≤ɛ, ∀x(t)∈D(x) and ∀t≥0.

Based on the result of Theorem 3, the system uncertainties in a compact subset D(x) and ∀t≥0, are assumed to be continuous and approximated by the following neural network: (17)hi(x,t)=W¯iTΨ(x)+ɛi(x,t),i=1,2 where W¯i∈ℜL×1 is an unknown constant matrix which is not necessarily unique, |ɛi(x,t)|≤ɛ∀x(t)∈D(x) and t≥0. In addition, the upper bound of W¯i is known, i.e., ||W¯i ||≤W¯im.

Then the following learning laws are considered. (18a)∧·Wi(t)=si(t)Γi-1Ψ(x)-αiΓi-1W∧i(t),i=1,2 where W∧i(t)∈ℜL×1 stands for the learning weight, Γi>0, αi>0 denotes an e-modification rate to ensure the boundedness of the learning weight, Ψ(x)∈ℜL×1 represents the basis function: (18b)Ψ(x)=[1ϕ2(x)…ϕL(x)]T where ϕj(x)=exp[- ||x(t)-dj ||2/σj2],L,dj,σj for j = 2, 3, … , L are known, and the centers dj for j=2,3,…,L are chosen as normal distribution in the corresponding domain. The nonlinear control gains i.e., b1a(x) and b2a(x) are unknown. However, their low bounds are supposed to be known, i.e., b1a(x)>b1al>0 and b2a(x)>b2al>0 for all x(t). Their upper bounds are also supposed to be existed, i.e., max{b1a(x)}≤b1am and max{b2a(x)}≤b2am for all x(t). Similarly, the learning laws for the functions b1a(x) and b2a(x) are designed as follows: (19a)∧·b1a(t)=s1(t)β1-1ψ1(t)-⪻[b∧1a(t),α3β1-1b∧1a(t)]∧·b2a(t)=s2(t)β2-1ψ2(t)-⪻[b∧2a(t),α4β2-1b∧2a(t)] where β1,β2,α3,α4>0, ψ1(t)=-W∧1T(t)ψ(x)/b∧1a(t),ψ2(t)=-W∧2T(t)Ψ(x)/b∧2a(t), and (19b)⪻g[b∧ia(t),αi+2βi-1b∧ia(t)g]=g{αi+2βi-1b∧ia(t)+αi+2βi-1g(bial-b∧ia(t)g)/δi,ifb∧ia(t)<bialαi+2βi-1b∧ia(t), otherwise,i=1,2g. where δ1,δ2>0. Once b∧1a(t)<b1al or b∧2a(t)<b2al occurs, the projection term in (19b) is employed to ensure that the corresponding learning quickly returns to its true region. In this situation, the occurrence of b∧1a(t) or b∧2a(t) approaching zero is avoided. Then the FDSMAUC is designed as follows: (20)ui(t)=ui,FDSMAUC(t)=gui[si(t)+Δi(t)sgn(si)]+W∧iT(t)Ψ(x)/(diab∧ia(t)),i=1,2 where gu1>γ1/d1ab1a(x)>0,gu2>γ2/d2ab2a(x)>0, and Δi(t)>0,i=1,2∀t. The small positive constantsγ1 and γ2>0 are employed to guarantee an exponential tracking to a convex set (22) (refer to the equation (E5)). The following theorem discusses the property of the FDSMAUC (20). Theorem 4
Consider the unknown electrical bicycle (2) with the known lower bounds of b1a(x)>b1al>0 and b2a(x)>b2al>0 for all x(t). The amplitudes of the switching gains Δ1(t) and Δ2(t) in (20) are selected such that the following inequalities are satisfied. (21)Δ1(t)>|ɛ1(x,t)|/(d1ab1a(x)gu1-γ1),Δ2(t)>|ɛ2(x,t)|/(d2ab2a(x)gu2-γ2)

If the control law (20) with the learning laws (18) and (19) is applied to the system (2), then {W∧1(t),W∧2(t),b∧1a(t),b∧2a(t),s1(t),s2(t),u1(t),u2(t)} are UUB, and the tracking performance is exponentially converged into the convex set: (22a)Da={s(t)∈ℜ2|0≤|s1(t)|≤θ1,0≤|s2(t)|≤θ2} where (22b)θi=-fi1+fi12+fi2,i=1,2 (22c)fi1={Δi(t)-|ɛi(x,t)|/(diabia(x)gui-γi)}/2>0,fi2={αi ||W¯im ||2+αi+2biam2}/(2diabia(x)gui-2γi) >0,i=1,2

sec.title: 4.3. Hybrid FDSMUC
sec.p: When the operating point is far away from the sliding surface, the learning law generally is not required so that the unnecessary instability and transient response are avoided, and then the dynamic balance can be guaranteed (Hwang, 2004). Although the controller in (20) is superior to that in (13), it is still a question when the learning law should be used. An important index for the sliding-mode control is the sliding surface. Due to the existence of system uncertainties, the operating point is always away from the sliding surface. Based on this knowledge, a scalar function f( ||s ||), where ||s ||=s12+s22, is designed as follows. When the norm of the sliding surfaces is inside of a defined set, the learning laws (18) and (19) start; similarly, as it is outside of the other set, the learning laws shut off. For reducing the possibility of discontinuous control input, a transition between the control (13) and the control (20) is consigned. Hence, we design the following scalar function: (23)f( ||s ||)={0, as ||s(t) ||>ns11, as ||s(t) ||<ns2(ns1- |s(t) |)/(ns1-ns2), otherwise where ns1>ds12+ds22>ns2>c12+c22>0. The values of ds12+ds22 and c12+c22 are respectively the upper bounds of the convergent sets of |s(t) | for the FDSMUC and FDSMAUC. Finally, the Hybrid FDSMUC is designed as follows: (24)ui(t)=ui,HYB(t)=guig[si(t)+Δi(t)sgn(si)g]+fg(g ||sg ||g)W∧iT(t)Ψ(x)/g(diab∧ia(t)g), i=1,2

If the system uncertainties are small enough, then the value of ds12+ds22 is also small enough. If the value of ds12+ds22 (or the system performance) satisfies the specification, then the value of ns1 approaches zero, i.e., the learning laws (18) and (19) can be shut down. The stability of the closed-loop system can be verified in the same way of section 4.1. For simplicity, it is omitted. On the other hand, the value of ds12+ds22 (or the system performance) is large, then the value of ns2 is away from zero, i.e., the learning laws (18) and (19) nearly executes all the time. The stability of the closed-loop system can be verified in a similar way of section 4.2. For brevity, it is omitted. As the state between section 4.1 and section 4.2, the linear combination of these two conditions is obtained.Based on the mean value theory (Hwang, 2004), the corresponding stability is assured. In addition, the comparisons among the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC are given in the next section. Remark 4
Because the coupled terms for a running electrical bicycle system are huge, in order to enhance the performance of Hybrid FDSMUC, the norm of sliding surfaces should be used instead of the individual absolute sliding surface of each subsystem (i.e., u|HYB|) : (25a)ui(t)=ui,|HYB|(t)=gui[si(t)+Δi(t)sgn(si)]+f(|si|)W∧iT(t)Ψ(x)/(diab∧ia(t)),i=1,2 where (25b)f(|si|)={0, as|si(t)|>nsi11, as|si(t)|<nsi2(nsi1-|si(t)|)/(nsi1-nsi2), otherwise

sec.title: 5. Simulations and discussions
sec.p: Consider the running electrical bicycle system (2) with the parameters shown in Table 1. According to the studies (Hwang et al., 2009), the modified proportional-derivative control (MPDC) can stabilize the electrical bicycle system, but it cannot get a better performance as compared with the proposed schemes. Moreover, in the presence of time-varying speed the MPDC will result in a risk of instability or transience. In this paper, the reference inputs of the lean angle, velocity and acceleration, and the reference inputs of the nominal steering acceleration, jerk and pendulum acceleration, jerk are assigned to be zero, i.e., r2(t)=r·2(t)=r··2(t)=0, r··1(t)=r··1(t)=0,r··3(t)=0, and r··3(t)=0. The coefficients of the sliding surfaces are set as follows: d1v=16.0,d1p=90,d2v=13.0,d2p=95,k1v=1.6,k1p=17, k2v=0.5 and k2p=11.8. The uncertainty of the multiplication form (i.e., ai(x)(1+Δai(x,t)), i=4,5,…8, b1(1+Δb1(x,t)), and b2(1+Δb2(x,t))) to represent the effect of c(x,t) is assumed to be: (26)Δa4(x,t)=1.5x1(t)x2(t)sin(0.3tx5(t))-0.37x3(t)x6(t)cos(0.2tx6(t))-0.2sin(100t)Δa5(x,t)=1.5x2(t)x3(t)sin(0.3tx6(t))-0.37x1(t)x4(t)cos(0.1tx5(t))-0.2cos(200t)Δa6(x,t)=1.5x3(t)x1(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.37x2(t)x5(t)cos(0.3tx4(t))+0.2sin(300t)Δa7(x,t)=1.0x4(t)x1(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.37x5(t)x8(t)cos(0.4tx8(t))-0.2sin(400t)Δa8(x,t)=1.0x5(t)x3(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.37x6(t)x7(t)cos(0.5tx7(t))+0.2sin(500t)Δb1(x,t)=0.3sin(-0.1+9.6tx3(t))+0.5sin(300t)Δb2(x,t)=0.3sin(0.1+6.9tx1(t))-0.5cos(100t)

This uncertainty is nonlinear time-varying and large. To compare the performances among the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC, the following larger uncertainty as compared with the uncertainty (26) is considered. (27)Δa4(x,t)=3.0x1(t)x2(t)sin(0.3tx5(t))-0.74x3(t)x6(t)cos(0.2tx6(t))-0.24sin(100t)Δa5(x,t)=3.0x2(t)x3(t)sin(0.3tx6(t))-0.74x1(t)x4(t)cos(0.1tx5(t))-0.24cos(200t)Δa6(x,t)=3.0x3(t)x1(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.74x2(t)x5(t)cos(0.3tx4(t))+0.24sin(300t)Δa7(x,t)=2.0x4(t)x1(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.74x5(t)x8(t)cos(0.4tx8(t))-0.24sin(400t) Δa8(x,t)=2.0x5(t)x3(t)sin(0.3tx4(t))+0.74x6(t)x7(t)cos(0.5tx7(t))+0.24sin(500t)Δb1(x,t)=0.36sin(-0.1+9.6tx3(t))+0.6sin(300t)Δb2(x,t)=0.36sin(0.1+6.9tx1(t))-0.6cos(100t).

The following simulations use the numerical algorithm of the fourth-order Runge-Kutta with time step0.01 second. The scaling factors of the FDSMUC are set as follows: gs1=0.03, gs·1=0.02, gu1=10, gs2=0.01,gs·2=0.02, and gu2=10. The parameters of frictional torques in (A.4) and (A.5) are assigned as Fs1+(Fs1-)=0.5(-0.5),Fs2+(Fs2-)=0.5(-0.5),δF1+(δF1-)=0.5(-0.4),δF2+(δF2-)=0.5(-0.4), C1+(C1-)=0.1,C2+(C2-)=0.1,θ·+(θ·-)=0.2(0.16),χ1=χ2=0.5 and ɛ=0.01. The response for the running electrical bicycle system in the presence of the uncertainty (26) by the FDSMUC is shown in Figure 2. The response of Figure 2 verifies the better robustness of the proposed FDSMUC for the uncertainty (26). However, the responses of the FDSMUC for huge uncertainty (e.g., the uncertainty (27)) become larger transience or more oscillatory (cf. Figure 3). It indicates that the performance of the FDSMUC is limited by the quantity of uncertainty. Under this circumstance, the FDSMAUC is considered. The corresponding response using the following scaling factors: Figure 2.
The responses of the running electrical bicycle system with the uncertainty (26) by the fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control. gs1=0.03, gs·1=0.02,gu1=10, gs2=0.01,gs·2=0.02,gu2=10, and the learning parameters: Γ1=diag{0.03}, Γ2=diag{0.04}, α1=0.1,α2=0.1, β1=3.0, β2=5.0, is shown in Figure 4, which is much better than that of Figure 3. The main reason is that the corresponding learning uncertainties in Figures 4(c) and (d) are good enough for the compensation of the uncertainties (the solid lines in Figures 4(c) and (d)). However, the transient response of the FDSMAUC caused by the initial error of the learning weight occurs. This feature probably destroys the dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle system. In this situation, the Hybrid FDSMUC is suggested to enhance system performance. Based on the norm of the sliding surface (i.e., Figure 2(c)), the suitable control parameters are selected as follows: ns1=50 and ns2=30. The corresponding response is shown in Figure 5, which is indeed better than that of the FDSMUC and FDSMAUC (cf. Figures 3(a), 4(a) and 5(a)). Figure 3.
The responses of the running electrical bicycle system with the huge uncertainty (27) by the fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control.
Figure 4.
The responses of the Figure 3 case by the fuzzy decentralized sliding mode adaptive under-actuated control.
Figure 5.
The responses of the Figure 3 case by the Hybrid fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control with ns1=50 and ns2=30.

For the consideration of practical situations (e.g., a gust of wind is blown to the bicycle), the following simulation with the uncertainty (27) is investigated. It is assumed that a gust of wind during the period 4.0–4.1 second brings about the extra effect of the lean angle 6∘ from 4.0 to 4.1 second. The corresponding results by the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC and Hybrid FDSMUC are then shown in Figures 6 and 7. From these two figures, we know that the resistance of the pulse disturbance by the Hybrid FDSMUC is superior to that of the FDSMUC and FDSMAUC. In addition, the response of the |Hybrid _ FDSMUC| with ns11=35andns22=23 shown in Figure 8 is compared with the result of the Hybrid FDSMUC in Figures 6(c) and 7(c). The comparison confirms the result in Remark 4. The norm of sliding surfaces should be used instead of the individual absolute sliding surface of each subsystem. In addition, some simulations about a bicycle manipulated under a variable speed with different frequency circumstance can refer to the paper (Hwang et al., 2009). Figure 6.
The system output responses of the Figure 5 case in the presence of the pulse disturbance of the lean angle6.0∘from 4.0 to 4.1 second by the fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control, fuzzy decentralized sliding mode adaptive under-actuated control and Hybrid fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control.
Figure 7.
The control input responses of the Figure 5 case in the presence of the pulse disturbance of the lean angle6.0∘from 4.0 to 4.1 second by the fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control, fuzzy decentralized sliding mode adaptive under-actuated control and Hybrid fuzzy decentralized sliding mode under-actuated control.
Figure 8.
The responses of the Figures 6 and 7 using theu|HYB|with ns11=35 and ns22=23.

Based on the above investigations, the important observations are depicted as follows:
The FDSMAUC can improve the performances of the FDSMUC for a running electrical bicycle system in the presence of huge uncertainty. However, a possible transient response occurs. In this situation, the dynamic balance of a running electrical bicycle system may be destroyed.
The proposed Hybrid FDSMUC indeed can enhance the system performance including the transient response and steady-state response; it also possesses excess robustness in comparison with the FDSMUC.
The resistance of the pulse disturbance (e.g., a gust of wind) by the Hybrid FDSMUC is better than that of the FDSMUC and FDSMAUC.
To enhance system performance, the design of the Hybrid FDSMUC should use the norm of sliding surfaces instead of the individual absolute sliding surface of each subsystem.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: An autonomous dynamic balance control scheme for a running electrical bicycle system in the presence of huge uncertainty by Hybrid FDSMUC is presented. The important characteristics of this paper are summarized as follows: (i) The inclusion of frictional torque and motor dynamics is to obtain more complete modeling of a running electrical bicycle. Based on two novel reference inputs, two sliding surfaces are individually obtained. Then the controlled system becomes two sliding surfaces and two control inputs. (ii) Only the input/output data of each subsystem and the information of the upper bound of system knowledge are required for the selection of three appropriate scaling factors of each subsystem, including two normalizing scaling factors for the sliding surface and its derivative, and one output scaling factor for the crisp control input. (iii)As the system uncertainty is huge, the Hybrid FDSMUC is applied to improve system performance including the avoidance of the unnecessary instability and transient response. Its corresponding control parameters are obtained according to that of FDSMUC and FDSMAUC. To enhance system performance, the design of the Hybrid FDSMUC should use the norm of sliding surfaces instead of the individual absolute sliding surface of each subsystem. (vi) The system performances, including the tracking performance for nonlinear time-varying uncertainty, generation of pulse disturbance to simulate wind effects, are acceptable for the FDSMUC, FDSMAUC, and Hybrid FDSMUC. In terms of the transient response and excess robustness, the performance of the Hybrid FDSMUC for huge uncertainty is better than that of the FDSMUC and FDSMAUC.

sec.title: Appendix A. The dynamics of the electrical bicycle including frictional torque and motor dynamics

sec.p: The dynamic equation of the front wheel part is first described as follows: (A.1)Ihθ··=τhan+fmgsinφ1+Iwωφ·1-(Ctφ1trcosθ+μωtrsinθ)-Ff1(θ·)

Then the dynamic equation of the bicycle body with the pendulum part is given as follows: (A.2)(Mbh2+Mpl12+Mpl22+2Mpl1l2cosφ2+J1+J2)φ··1 -(Mpl22+Mpl1l2cosφ2+J2)φ··2 -2Mpl1l2sinφ2φ·1φ·2+Mpl1l2sinφ2φ·22 -Mbghsinφ1-Mpgl1sinφ1+Mpgl2sin(φ2-φ1) +(Mbl1cosφ1+Mpl2cosφ1+Mpl2cos(φ2-φ1)) (V2θ+L1Vθ·)/L=0 (A.3)-(Mpl22+Mpl1l2cosφ2+J2)φ··1+(Mpl22+J2)φ··2+Mpl1l2sinφ2φ·12-Mpgl2sin(φ2-φ1)-Mpl2cos(φ2-φ1)(V2θ+L1Vθ·)/L=τpen-Ff2(φ·2) where the internal Coulomb friction torques Ffi(·),i=1,2 including sticking and slipping torques can be approximated by a nonlinear function of velocity and be represented as follows: (A.4)Ffi(·)=Fslipi(·)ρ(·)+Fsticki(ui)[1-ρ(·)], i=1,2 where the values of ρ(·) equal to 1 as |θ·(·)|>ɛ , and ρ(·)=0, otherwise. Fsticki(ui)=g{Fsi+ui/χiFsi-g.ui/χi>Fsi+>0Fsi-≤ui/χi≤Fsi+ui/χi<Fsi-<0Fslipi(θ·)=g{Fki+(θ·)=Fsi+-δFi+g{1-expg[-g|θ·/θ·+g|g]g} +Ci+θ·,θ·>0Fki-(θ·)=Fsi--δFi-g{1-expg[-g|θ·/θ·-g|g]g} +Ci-θ·,θ·≤0(A.5),i=1,2 Figure A1.
Control mechanism of an electrical bicycle system

Furthermore, considering the motor dynamics, firstly the relation between the joint position and the motor shaft position is given by θm=N1θ,φm=N2φ2. The relation between dynamics of armature-controlled dc motors at the electrical bicycle system and applied torques of steering handle and pendulum is respectively described as follows: (A.6)L¯1i·1+R1i1+Kb1θ·m=u1,L¯2i·2+R2i2+Kb2φ·m=u2 where R1,R2,L¯1 and L¯2 are the resistances and the inductances of the armature circuit at individual control axes, Kb1 and Kb2 are the back electromotive force (EMF) constants of the motor, i1 and i2 are the armature current, and u1 and u2 are the input voltages for steering handle and pendulum, respectively. The torques of steering handle and pendulum at the joint side are related to the armature currents by (A.7)τhan=N1Kt1i1,τpen=N2Kt2i2 where N1 and N2>0 are the gear ratio at individual axis, and Kt1 and Kt2>0 are the motor torque constants.

sec.title: Appendix B. The proof of lemma 3
sec.p: Applying Lemma 2 to (3) and (4) with the fact |s1|<α0 ||e¯1 || and |s2|<α1 ||e¯3 || , then {e1,e·1,e3,e·3} are bounded and |e1|,|e·1|,|e3|,|e·3|→0 as t→∞. Similarly, based on the results |r1|,|r3|<max(k1p,k2p)|e2| and Lemma 3, {e2,e·2} is bounded and |e2|,|e·2|→0 as t→∞. Because r2=r·2=0, |x2|,|x5|→0 as t→∞. Then from the inequalities |r1|,|r3|<max(k1p,k2p)|e2| and |r·1|,|r·3|<k0|e·2|, r1,r·1,r3,r·3→0 as t→∞. Hence, the result that |x1|,|x3|,|x4|,|x6|→0 as t→∞, is derived from |e1|,|e·1|,|e3|,|e·3|→0 as t→∞.

sec.title: Appendix C. The proof of lemma 4
sec.p: Based on Lemma 2, {e1,e·1,e3,e·3} are bounded and |e1|,|e·1|,|e3|,|e·3|→0 as t→∞. Applying Lemma 1 to (5) and (6) with the satisfaction of |r1|<p1 and |r3|<q1 obtains |e2|<p1/k1p,|e·2|<2p1/k1v and |e2|<q1/k2p, |e·2|<2q1/k2v, respectively. Finally, based on the definitions of (7) and triangular inequality, the corresponding results are obtained.

sec.title: Appendix D. The proof of lemma 5
sec.p: Applying Lemma 1 respectively to (3) and (4) with |s1|<p0 and |s2|<q0 gives |e¯1 |≤p0k1/k2 and |e¯3 |≤q0k3/k4 respectively, where k1,k2,k3 and k4 are positive constants which can be determined by the result of Remark 1. Similarly, the inequality |r1|<p1 for (5) and the inequality |r3|<q1 for (6) yield |e2|<p1/k1p, |e·2|<2p1/k1v and |e2|<q1/k2p, |e·2|<2q1/k2v, respectively. Finally, based on the definitions of (7) and triangular inequality, the corresponding results are accomplished.

sec.title: Appendix E. The proof of theorem 4
sec.p: At beginning, the following Lyapunov function is defined. (E.1)V={s12+s22+W~1TΓ1W~1+W~2TΓ2W~2+β1b~1a2+β2b~2a2}/2 where W~1=W¯1-W∧1,W~2=W¯2-W∧2,b~1a=b1ab∧1a,and b~2a=b2a-b∧2a. It is obvious that V>0 as s1≠0 or s2≠0 or b~1a≠0 or b~2a≠0. Based on the relation of (E1), we have the following results: (E.2)W~1TW∧1=gg||W¯1g||2-g||W~1g||2-g||W∧1g||2g/2,W~2TW∧2=gg||W¯2g||2-g||W~2g||2-g||W∧2g||2g/2 (E.3)b~1ab∧1a={b1a2-b~1a2-b∧1a2}/2,b~2ab∧2a={b2a2-b~2a2-b∧2a2}/2

We first consider the case: b∧1a≥b1al and b∧2a≥b2al. Taking the time derivative of (E.1), substituting equations (10), (11), (15), (16), (17)–(19) (E.2) and (E.3) into the time derivative of (E.1), and using the fact d1ab1a>0 and d2ab2a>0 ∀x, yields (E.4)s2Ψ-α2Ŵ2) -b~1a(s1Ψ1-α3b̂1a)-b~2a(s2Ψ2-α4b̂2a) =s1h1-(d1ab1agu1-γ1)s12-|s1|d1ab1agu1Δ1 -s1Ŵ1TΨb1a/b̂1a+s2h2-(d2ab2agu2-γ2)s22 -|s2|d2ab2agu2Δ2-s2Ŵ2TΨb2a/b̂2a -W~1T(s1Ψ-α1Ŵ1)-W~2T(s2Ψ-α2Ŵ2) -b~1a(s1Ψ1-α3b̂1a)-b~2a(s2Ψ2-α4b̂2a) -(γ1s12+γ2s22) =s1(W¯1TΨ+ɛ1)-s1Ŵ1TΨ(1+b~1a/b̂1a) +s2(W¯2TΨ+ɛ2)-s2Ŵ2TΨ(1+b~2a/b̂2a) -W~1T(s1Ψ-α1Ŵ1)-W~2T(s2Ψ-α2Ŵ2) -b~1a(s1Ψ1-α3b̂1a)-b~2a(s2Ψ2-α4b̂2a) -(d1ab1agu1-γ1)s12-|s1|d1ab1agu1Δ1 -(d2ab2agu2-γ2)s22-|s2|d2ab2agu2Δ2-(γ1s12+γ2s22) ≤-(d1ab1agu1-γ1)|s1|{|s1|+Δ1-|ɛ1|/(d1ab1agu1-γ1)} -(d2ab2agu2-γ2)|s2|{|s2|+Δ2-|ɛ2|/(d2ab2agu2-γ2)} +α1{ ||W¯1 ||2- ||W~1 ||2- ||W∧1 ||2}/2 +α2{ ||W¯2 ||2- ||W~2 ||2- ||W∧2 ||2}/2 +α3{b1a2-b~1a2-b∧1a2}/2 +α4{b2a2-b~2a2-b∧2a2}/2-(γ1s12+γ2s22) =-(γ1s12+γ2s22)-α1 ||W~1 ||2-α2 ||W~2 ||2 -α3b~1a2-α4b~2a2-(d1ab1agu1-γ1)F1(|s1|) -(d2ab2agu2-γ2)F2(|s2|) +α1{ ||W¯1 ||2- ||W¯1m ||2- ||W∧1 ||2}/2 +α2{ ||W¯2 ||2- ||W¯2m ||2- ||W∧2 ||2}/2 +α3{b1a2-b1am2-b∧1a2}/2+α4{b2a2-b2am2-b∧2a2}/2 where (E.5)F1(|s1|)=|s1|2+2f11|s1|-f12,F2(|s2|)=|s2|2+2f21|s2|-f22

The corresponding coefficients of the polynomials F1(|s1|) and F2(|s2|) are expressed in (22c). Because ||W¯1 ||2- ||W¯1m ||2≤0, ||W¯2 ||2- |W¯2m |2≤0,b1a2-b1am2≤0 and b2a2-b2am2≤0, if F1(|s1|)>0 and F2(|s2|)>0, the following result is achieved. (E.6)V·≤-μV where μ=min{min[γ1,0.5],min[γ2,0.5],-min[α1,0.5λ(Γ1)],min[α2,0.5λ(Γ2)],min[α3,0.5β1],min[α4,0.5β2]} It reveals that the signals s1,s2,W~1,W~2,b~1a, and b~2a exponentially converge to specific domains, which are connected with uncertainty. In summary, when |s1|>θ1 and |s2|>θ2 are obtained (i.e., outside of the domain Da in (22a)), the closed-loop system possesses the result V·≤-μV. Hence, the signal s exponentially converges into the domain Da (22). Therefore, from (3), (4), (18), (19) and (20) {s1,s2,W~1,W~2,b~1a,b~2a} are UUB.

Similarly, the case: b∧1a<b1al and b∧2a<b2al is considered as follows. The difference between these two cases is whether the learning laws (19a) include theprojection. Then the time derivative of Lyapunov function becomes the equation (E.4) with two extra terms: (E.7)V·≤[right hand side of (E4)]-α3b~1a(b1al-b∧1a)/δ1 -α4b~2a(b2al-b∧2a)/δ2

Because 0<b1al-b∧1a,0<b2al-b∧2a,-b~1a =-(b1a-b∧1a)<-(b1al-b∧1a) and -b~2a=-(b2a-b∧2a)<-(b2al-b∧2a) (E.8) becomes more negative than (E.4). (E.8)V·≤[right hand side of (E4)]-α3(b1al-b∧1a)2/δ1 -α4(b2al-b∧2a)2/δ2
Finally, the same results of the above-mentioned situation: b∧1a≥b1al and b∧2a≥b2al, is obtained.
